sentence: Everyone loves an underdog, but when you're an investor, having the courage and patience to buy an underperforming stock in hopes of a turnaround can be quite nerve-racking.
Therefore, we asked three Motley Fool contributors for their top underdog ideas.
They offered J.C. Penney , GameStop , and King Digital , along with some rather compelling reasons why.
Be sure to share your thoughts with fellow Fools in the comments box below the article.
This isn't the first time J.C. Penney has been left for dead by analysts, and it probably won't be the last.

Yet the old-line retailer has more than once surprised Wall Street with its ability to resurrect itself and despite the dour outlook the pros have for the department store chain, I don't think it will be the last time for that either.
Penney's problems this time, though, are partially a result of its own mismanagement of expectations.

The company gave the impression it would be experiencing a strong flow-through following the back-to-school season, but when it updated analysts at a conference in early October, it suggested that traffic fell off the table after the kids returned to school.
And after reporting results on Wednesday, the retailer came up short of a fourth consecutive quarter of rising sales.
I find J.C. Penney still has a lot to commend it, and as it's done several times over the past year or so, will ultimately surprise the markets once again.

Although comps came in flat this quarter, it still reiterated its guidance for margins and SG&A, reaffirmed its full-year guidance, including same-store sales coming in in the mid-single-digit comp range -- suggesting a stronger fourth quarter finish to the year -- and perhaps even more importantly, says it will be free cash flow positive by year's end.
With a new chief executive officer taking the reins of this retailer, one who has strong store operation skills following over a decade of work at Home Depot .
While some may have wanted a more daring pick to take over from turnaround specialist Mike Ullman, the last time they did that it almost drove them over the brink.
Marvin Ellison is a safe choice, to be sure, but one that should give the retailer's recovery time to work.
I see the plunge in J.C. Penney's stock as a good, long-term opportunity to buy into this stock.
Demitrios Kalogeropoulos : Video game retailer GameStop isn't popular in investment circles.
The stock is down 17% over the last year, underperforming the market by 34 points.
Short interest in October climbed to over one third of the outstanding share count.
And GameStop sports a lowly one-star rating in The Motley Fool's CAPS community.
The bearish thesis sounds as logical as it does scary: GameStop will quickly wither away as video game selling goes digital.
But I'm not so sure.
The company last quarter tightened its dominant grip on the surging video game market.
Popular Xbox One and Playstation 4 devices, along with a few hit games, drove a 22% spike in same-store sales.
Profit margin clocked in at a hefty 32%.
Sure, that's down from the prior year, but only because a fresh generation of video game consoles is pushing the trade-in business to the sidelines as GameStop sells a higher proportion of new stuff.
Profits have the potential to spike higher as this generation matures.
GameStop has also been busy tacking additional revenue streams on to its traditional business.
Consumer electronics, for one, is a natural fit within its buy-sell-trade model.
Acquiring Spring Mobile and Cricket Wireless brands has added smartphone services to the mix.
Altogether, GameStop is expecting plenty of demand from its three biggest product categories this holiday season.
The company plans to hire 25,000 seasonal employees across its portfolio of stores for a 50% boost over last year.
Yes, the digital-selling trend is a serious challenge that GameStop will have to face.
But in the meantime this is a retailer that's dominating a fast-growing category while branching out to some promising new business lines.
King Digital might be the quintessential example of an underdog.
Its stock has collapsed 26% since its March IPO, but not necessarily because of its own operating performance, but rather the history of fellow mobile gaming companies like Zynga.
That said, King Digital has answered many of the questions bestowed upon it.
Investors knew that eventually Candy Crush Saga would run out of steam, and that King Digital would have to find alternative ways replace lost revenue when that day came.
While Candy Crush Saga remains the second highest daily grossing app, at just under a million bucks per day according to ThinkGaming.com , King Digital has lessened its dependence on the title.
In 2013, Candy Crush accounted for 80% of King Digital's total gross bookings, but in its third quarter it represented just 51% of total bookings.
This was possible thanks to 167% year-over-year bookings growth in titles excluding Candy Crush during its last quarter.

That said, King Digital has three total games that rank in the top 10 of ThinkGaming.com's list of total grossing gaming apps, and many more, such as Diamond Digger Saga , that are climbing the charts fast.

Candy Crush 's days of triple-digit-bookings growth may be gone, but given King's ability to capitalize on many titles, while also keeping Candy Crush as a top-grossing app for nearly two years, serves as a good reason not to bet against the company.
At just 6.5 times trailing 12-month earnings, it's a good underdog to keep your eye on.

Top dividend stocks for the next decade

The smartest investors know that dividend stocks simply crush their non-dividend paying counterparts over the long term.
That's beyond dispute.
They also know that a well-constructed dividend portfolio creates wealth steadily, while still allowing you to sleep like a baby.
Knowing how valuable such a portfolio might be, our top analysts put together a report on a group of high-yielding stocks that should be in any income investor's portfolio.
